Higashi no Eden 8/10
Story: 9/10
This was a really short but nice story about a guy who lost his memories and tries to remember who he was and what he did in his life before, and in that process realizes that he is part of a disturbing game. The anime shows how a person can change just by loosing his memories, how he can be lost and what he would do to get his memories back. Also it shows some really interesting things like "what would you do if you could do anything you want?" would you save the world, destroy it or probably let itbe just like it is. It's strange how people can be different when you ask such questions, and you can see all that in this anime, that's why i recommend it highly to watch.


Characters: 8/10


There is one part i didn't really like: the short amount of time you have to learn and understand the characters you just saw, because there are so many of them and you have to realize what they are thinking, and that wasn't really easy to do in just 11 episodes. But on the other side, that made it even more interesting, it was like seeing small plot twists every episode.


Animations: 8/10


Anime aired 6 years ago, but the animations are quite interesting and well made, there are characters who look a bit strange but i think that was to characterize the character itself, it was kinda needed to draw them like that. For the surroundings and colors, really fine made, can't complain much.


Music: 8/10


Opening theme: I haven't heard a English opening for so long and when i listened to it i didn't liked it at first, but after hearing it a few times i realized how it fits with the anime, that calm sound and lyrics, they DID choose a good opening for the series.

Ending theme: I like the ending theme even more, it was such a nice one and it ended every episode in such a nice way that it made me love the ending 

For the background music, i have to say that i didn't really paid attention to it, co i could say that it wasn't anything special, but also not bad, cause then i would realize it for sure.



Closing words:


Even if the anime is really short, and you are probably thinking there is no way they could put up a good story in such short time, try watching it and you will realize that you were wrong.

Also, there are 2 movies of this anime i have to watch, it's a direct sequel to the story.

That's really my only problem with the show, they present you with so many characters and you never really get to know any of them, so when the series ended, I was left with this sort of incomplete feeling, like this world was not fully explored.

I didn't really like Eden of the East. The story has something to offer, but eleven episodes are just not enough to really introduce any characters or answer any questions. One has to watch the movies too, and after seeing the anime I am not really inclined to spending another couple of hours watching them. To me it looks like the producers weren't completely sure about what to produce: The style jumps back and forth between slapstick humor and strong violence (lots people being killed and getting their "johnnies" chopped off), always avoiding to settle for the one or the other. Too much time is"wasted" on a couple of characters which do not really contribute much to the story, like Saki and her friends. To be honest: I hated Saki from the beginning. She is a textbook example for the pathetic, self-centered, useless female character so many anime creators seem to think they have to include.\n\n
Back in 2009 people probably didn't have much choice, but nowadays i would suggest to skip Eden of the East for Mirai Nikki or Steins;Gate. If you have seen Yuno in action, you won't shed a tear for Saki.

So I was kinda disappointed but I still enjoyed it.

Eden of The East has a very strange concept behind this and somewhat is a bit controversial or bring some topical allusions to it. From Production I.G., who brought us The Ghost in The Shell franchise, Blood: The Last Vampire, Blood+, Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade & the anime sequence in Kill Bill, Vol. 1. And this series is directed by Kenji Kamiyama, who also directed the GITS TV Series.
11/22/10, ten missiles strike uninhabited areas of Japan, but on the bright side, no victims were harmed and it was named Careless Monday and no one really cared about that. This situation still does occur throughout theshow.


Meet Saki Morimi, a young Japanese woman visiting Washington D.C. on a trip and then she meets an mysterious Japanese man, whose introduction is mostly him being naked carrying a gun and a cell phone with the amount of ¥8.2 billion in digital money but apparently you know waving a gun on the nation’s capital isn’t a grand idea. The guy goes by Akira (not that one) Takizawa and he is part of some game where it consists of a Seleção of 12 individuals that are given ¥10 billion to save Japan in some way with help from the phone operator named Juiz to fulfill any order for a price but used the money for your own selfish needs, you are instantly eliminated.


But I bet you wonder this: “Who the hell are the Eden of The East?” Good question.


The name comes from the name of a cell phone application developed by Saki’s friends, which is mostly a much-improved version of Facebook, Twitter and YouTube mashed in together. The members include: Satoshi Ōsugi, Saki’s friend who does, in fact, has a crush on Saki but when she neglects him for Akira, the typical love triangle or something like that happens; Kazuomi Hirasawa, the de facto leader who wants to create a NEET Paradise; Mikuru Katsuhara, or Micchan, the talented yet shy and frank (also a character I can relate to….a little and cute, too) programmer who programmed the image recognition system and Yutaka Itazu, a prodigal reclusive hacker whose nickname is “Panties” because he lost his pants and never went outside again.


There is another character Kuroha Diana Shiratori, who is a president of a model agency by day and a mysterious serial killer who kill men by cutting off their penises and yes, that does sound like it hurt like hell but she only kills rapists so if you’re respectful to women, you are safe.



FINAL VERDICT: This is an so-so and mostly innovative show but kind of hard to understand when watching it for the first time, much like Ghost in The Shell, both the movies and the series. The main characters are decent but the supporting characters did a top-notch job.  Both the animation is really superb and vivid. The themes of this show are slightly controversial but it is mostly done in a subtle way and the music is acceptable, although I wonder why that one theme song in the 1st episode by Oasis was used only once but used another one for the reminder. But I am not done with this franchise yet…….there is still 2 more entries, but that’s for another day. Now I bid you Noblesse Oblige.

*Another short review! Because I can!*
A meet-cute romance spliced with a Bourne-esque mystery. I can report that this splicing works pleasantly well, and the cutesy character design, voice actors, and script writers all work together in harmony to produce something that's sort of special--it's not going to blow your mind or rock your world or anything, but it's thoroughly engaging while it's running. Some typical anime weirdness does intrude a bit here and there, and the series ends very abruptly, leaving many plot points unresolved--though there are two movie sequels that right this flaw, albeit in a pretty unsatisfactory way, in my opinion. Still, highlyrecommended.

Lol sorry to everyone just had to do that cause that saying is awesome but let's get to the review.
Eden of the East is I guess you would call a  mystery/romance/action that's very interesting throughout its run.
Story 8: 
Eden of the East starts off pretty interesting with our main character Takizawa standing naked, with no memory, holding a gun and a cell phone in front of the white house. After seeing our second main character Saki, who decides to take he anger out on the white house by throwing a quarter he decides tohelp her by getting the attention on him. After this he's pretty much just trying to figure out who he is and what's happened in his past and what's going on with his weird phone. The story actually progresses very well being slow at times and pumping it up at others but it makes it all feel very smooth. The story for some reason actually feels very American which I think it was going for since it even mentions the Borne films and Taxi, its very well done the way that American movie style and anime mix very well in the story. The one complaint I have is something I've been seeing a bit lately, its that as someone watching you figure certain things out and then you're looking at the character and you're like 'why haven't you figured this out yet you have almost the exact same info as me?' As an anime that's trying to be hidden in mystery you figure certain things out pretty fast if you just pay attention and in the end its really rewarding but you kinda want to scream at the characters a bit.

Eden of the East is a very good anime with a bit of mystery that's very satisfying as things become uncovered. The only thing is that to finish the series you have two movies to pick up after but I loved watching this series.

The anime had very good potential, but for me it didn’t really live up to it. The story started off very intriguing - a naked guy who’s supposedly a terrorist has lost all his memory. Oh yeah, I don’t think we ever found out why he was in that situation in the first place...which leads me to point out that there were many unanswered questions left in the anime. How exactly does Juiz work? What was with those white zombie johnnys? Were those just figments of his imagination? What was up with the other Selecaos? Who exactly was the Supporter? How did Selecaos get selectedin the first place? Plot flaws aside, the characters were very weak as well. Pretty much every single character was plain and stereotypical, besides Akira. But even he wasn’t all that great as he went through no development at all (just like all the other characters) Akira - This character was honestly only mediocre at best. Had a really interesting entrance at the beginning, but ultimately he turned out to be “the charming boy with a dark background”. Saki - Typical teenage girl that falls in love with the “bad boy”. Osugi - The desperate boy that gets friendzoned. Itazu - Stereotypical NEET. Obese, shut in, 1337 hax0r that can somehow crack down a highly confidential system in a matter of minutes\n
So yeah, unfortunately I don’t really have the interest left to watch the movies. This anime was quite disappointing for me. Might only be because one of my friends hyped it up like crazy. But still, there were too many flaws for me to enjoy it all that much.

OMG Higashi no Eden was very blissful. Honestly the amount of cliffhangers made the entire show amazing. Takizawa and Saki are the best combo out there. The fact that so much can happen in only knowing someone for 11 days. And the phone plays an important part in the development o the series. The anime gets tied in with 2 movies because of the suspense that is created and it's just asking for more!

My appraisal:
From also taking into account the two films (they are not proper entities through directly following on from the last episode and hence shouldn’t be treated as such) it can conclusively be said that the crew have proved themselves as highly proficient in making an otherwise well-rounded piece but that such an ambitiously grand-scale concept was still beyond their full grasp.
The premise had the possibility to become an engagingly hypothetical- and profoundly relevant during its initial airing- look at how the infrastructure of society can be subtly manipulated and improved upon but it is largely squandered in the fleshing out of the story thatis too insistent on bringing in action sequences. With being nonsensically forced into a life-or-death game (it does appear logical but is actually rather ill-conceived and counterproductive) the characters who are given a reasonable opportunity to put their ideas to fruition often don’t take it to heart through instead resorting to extremism (in the loosest sense) and spitefully playing cat-and-mouse. There are glimpses of innovative ideologies with far-reaching consequences but ultimately this production is content in remaining as an effective outlet for the grievances of those feeling suppressed in a saturated society and the committee would be wise to reboot this and realize its true potential.

Eden of the East sucks. Now, don't get me wrong, there's definitely some clever ideas scattered throughout this anime, but as an anime it's all over the place. The premise, 12 individuals receive special phones, access to a huge sum of money, and the task of "saving Japan" is definitely interesting, as the vague goal allows for different people to reach different conclusions on what "saving Japan" means. The main character (Takizawa)  is savior number 9, but he suffers from amnesia, which he quickly discovers is a result from his own decision to erase his memories. This to is a clever way to drawin the audience as we follow his quest to solve the mystery of who he is "Jason Bourne" style. Sadly, it's all downhill from there, which is extremely disappointing to me, because a good friend recommended highly this anime to me as one of the best he'd ever seen, and at first I was really interested to see where they would go with it. Well, by the time the story introduces a character called "the johnny hunter," a psycho bitch who literally abducts men and cuts their genitals off (no, I'm not kidding), I realized the true nature of this god awful anime. It takes a special kind of stupid to think up a character and story arc as unpleasant and ridiculous as this one and attempt to pass it off as a serious development. This isn't mere fan service (sure the woman walks around in her underwear, because why not, right?) or just quirky bizarre anime humor, this is a genuinely revolting amount of excess. Try to imagine the situation reversed: a man abducts little girls and tortures them to death by mutilating their sexual organs. THAT is sick. And this is equally sick. This anime makes me sick. It's one of the biggest missed opportunities I've ever seen. We've seen so many fantastic anime that push the boundaries of what anime can be, and this one had the potential to go the distance, but boy oh boy did it fail spectacularly at that. What a waste of my time.
